review.title: Relaxation-based revision operators in description logics
review.abstract: As ontologies and description logics (DLs) reach out to a broader audience, several reasoning services are developed in this context. Belief revision is one of them, of prime importance when knowledge is prone to change and inconsistency. In this paper we address both the generalization of the well-known AGM postulates, and the definition of concrete and well-founded revision operators in different DL families. We introduce a model-theoretic version of the AGM postulates with a general definition of inconsistency, hence enlarging their scope to a wide family of non-classical logics, in particular negation-free DL families. We propose a general framework for defining revision operators based on the notion of relaxation, introduced recently for defining dissimilarity measures between DL concepts. A revision operator in this framework amounts to relax the set of models of the old belief until it reaches the sets of models of the new piece of knowledge. We demonstrate that such a relaxation-based revision operator defines a faithful assignment and satisfies the generalized AGM postulates. Another important contribution concerns the definition of several concrete relaxation operators suited to the syntax of some DLs (ALC and its fragments EL and ELU).

sections.text: It is the process of transforming an agent belief with a newly acquired knowledge. Three operations of change are usually considered: expansion, contraction and revision. Here we focus on revision, i.e. the process of consequent addition of new beliefs. The revision of faith has been intensively studied in classical logic (e.g. proposition logic), mainly through the prism of AGM theory [Alchourro-n et al., 1985]. sections.heading: 2.2 AGM theory and Description Logics
sections.text: AGM theory [Alchourro ́ n et al., 1985] is probably the most influential paradigm in verification theory [Ga ¼ rdenfors, 2003]. It provides, on an abstract logical level, a set of postulates that should satisfy a revision operator in order to bring the old belief minimally and rationally into line with the new one. These postulates require that logic be closed under negation and common propositional connectives (which prevents its use in many non-classical logics, including DLs). Indeed, many DLs do not allow negation of concepts (e.g. EL) and a fortiori disjuncture between TBox and ABox theorems that are not defined in all DLs. Recently, many papers have addressed the adaptation of AGM theory to non-classical logic, e.g. [Flouris et al., 2005; Delde and Peppas, 2015; Ribeiro and Aquarius].

sections.heading: 5 Related works
sections.text: While most of them focused on the adaptation of the AGM theory, only a few papers focused on the definition of concrete operators [Meyer et al., 2005; Qi et al., 2006a; Qi et al., 2006b]. A closely related field is inconsistency in ontologies (e.g. [Schlobach and Cornet, 2003; Schlobach et al., 2007]), the main difference being that the rationality of inconsistencies that operators repair is not studied, as AGM theory suggests. Some of our relaxation operators are closely related to those introduced in [Qi et al., 2006b] for the knowledge bases of revision and in [Gorogiannis and Hunter, 2008] for the merging of best-class theories.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The contribution of this paper is threefold: firstly, we have proposed a generalization of the AGM postulates so that they can be applied to a broad class of non-classical logics; secondly, we have proposed a general framework for defining revision operators on the basis of the concept of relaxation; we have shown that such a relaxation-based framework for faith revisions satisfies the AGM postulates and leads to a faithful allocation; thirdly, we have introduced a series of concrete relaxations, discussed their properties and illustrated them using simple examples; the future work will deal with investigating the complexity of these operators, comparing their induced sequence and generalization to other non-classical logic such as horn logic; this work was partly funded by the French ANR project LOGIMA.
